Adverbs: Use correct word order in grammar
Direct and Reported Speech: Use reported speech: pronoun and time word changes
Use reported speech: verb form changes
Future Verb Forms: Distinguish 'be going to' and 'will' for future
Past Verb Forms: Distinguish past simple and past continuous
Distinguish past simple and past perfect
Distinguish past simple and present perfect
Present Verb Forms: Distinguish present simple and present continuous
Sentence Formation: Use correct word order in grammar

Listening Genres and Purposes: Listen to and understand a discussion
Listen to and understand a lecture
Listen to and understand a story
Listen to and understand an interview

Reading Genres and Purposes: Identify facts and opinions in text

Speaking Skills and Strategies: Make and respond to a suggestion orally

Vocabulary Acquisition: Understand and use describing words
Understand and use feeling words
Understand and use idioms
Understand and use new words
Understand and use number words
Understand and use opinion words
Understand and use words about activities and habits
Understand and use words about personalities

Understand and use words about the body and health
Understand and use words about time
Understand and use words about travel and transportation
Understand and use words about weather and environment
Understand and use words about work and jobs
Understand and use words for animals
Vocabulary Skills and Strategies: Categorize words in order to understand them

Addressing audiences: Can give a prepared presentation on a familiar topic within their field, outlining similarities and differences (e.g. between products, countries/regions, plans).
Coherence and cohesion: Can introduce a counter-argument in a simple discursive text (e.g. with 'however').
Correspondence: Can compose basic formal e-mails/letters (e.g. to make a complaint and request action).
Creative writing: Can clearly signal chronological sequence in narrative text.
General linguistic range: Has a sufficient range of language to describe unpredictable situations, explain the main points in an idea or problem with reasonable precision and express thoughts on abstract or cultural topics such as music and film.
Grammatical accuracy: Communicates with reasonable accuracy in familiar contexts; generally good control, though with noticeable mother-tongue influence. Errors occur, but it is clear what they are trying to express.
Identifying cues and inferring (spoken,: Can exploit different types of connectors (numerical, temporal, logical) and the role of key paragraphs in the overall organisation in order to better understand the argumentation in a text.
Can extrapolate the meaning of a section of a text by taking into account the text as a whole.
Can extrapolate the meaning of occasional unknown words/signs from the context and deduce sentence meaning, provided the topic discussed is familiar.
Can identify the meaning of unfamiliar words/signs from the context on topics related to their field and interests.
Informal discussion (with friends): Can compare and contrast alternatives, discussing what to do, where to go, who or which to choose, etc.
Can explain why something is a problem.
Can express their thoughts about abstract or cultural topics such as music or films.
Can follow much of what is said around them on general topics, provided interlocutors avoid very idiomatic usage and articulate clearly.
Interviewing and being interviewed: Can provide concrete information required in an interview/consultation (e.g. describe symptoms to a doctor), but with limited precision.
Notes, messages and forms: Can take routine messages that are likely to occur in a personal, professional or academic context.
Overall oral interaction: Can communicate with some confidence on familiar routine and non-routine matters related to their interests and professional field. Can exchange, check and confirm information, deal with less routine situations and explain why something is a problem. Can express thoughts on more abstract, cultural topics such as films, books, music, etc.
Reading for information and argument: Can identify the main conclusions in clearly signalled argumentative texts.

Can understand short texts on subjects that are familiar or of current interest, in which people give their points of view (e.g. critical contributions to an online discussion forum or readers’ letters to the editor).
Can understand straightforward, factual texts on subjects relating to their interests or studies.
Reading for orientation: Can scan longer texts in order to locate desired information, and gather information from different parts of a text, or from different texts in order to fulfil a specific task.
Can scan through straightforward, factual texts in magazines, brochures or on the web, identify what they are about and decide whether they contain information that might be of practical use.
Reading instructions: Can understand instructions and procedures in the form of a continuous text, for instance in a manual, provided they are familiar with the type of process or product concerned.
Reports and essays: Can produce a text on a topical subject of personal interest, using simple language to list advantages and disadvantages, and give and justify their opinion.
Can produce short, simple essays on topics of interest.
Sustained monologue: describing experien: Can clearly express feelings about something experienced and give reasons to explain those feelings.
Sustained monologue: giving information: Can describe how to do something, giving detailed instructions.
Can explain the main points in an idea or problem with reasonable precision.
Sustained monologue: putting a case (e.g: Can develop an argument well enough to be followed without difficulty most of the time.
Can give simple reasons to justify a viewpoint on a familiar topic.
Understanding audio (or signed) media an: Can understand the information content of the majority of recorded or broadcast material on topics of personal interest delivered in clear standard language.
Understanding conversation between other: Can follow much of everyday conversation and discussion, provided it is clearly articulated in standard language or in a familiar variety.
Using telecommunications: Can use telecommunications for everyday personal or professional purposes, provided they can ask for clarification from time to time.
